question: He used perpetually to set the quiet dining-room into [MASK] of merriment, as he stole to his place after the bell had tapped for prayers; he seemed so perfectly awkward.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: A long, straggling fellow he is, brown and hard-haired, who seems to be growing straight out of his clothes, and walks with a half-apologetic roll.
next_sentence: And yet one glance at his face made one forgive him much,âthat broad, good-natured smile in which lay no bit of art or artifice, but seemed just bubbling good-nature and genuine satisfaction with the world.

question: Teach thinkers to think, âa needed knowledge in a day of loose and careless logic; and they whose lot is gravest must have the carefulest [MASK] to think aright.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: Teach workers to work,âa wise saying; wise when applied to German boys and American girls; wiser when said of Negro boys, for they have less knowledge of working and none to teach them.
next_sentence: If these things are so, how foolish to ask what is the best education for one or seven or sixty million souls!

question: Behind all its curiousness, so attractive alike to sage and dilettante, lie its dim dangers, throwing across us shadows at once [MASK] and awful.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: This is the tangle of thought and afterthought wherein we are called to solve the problem of training men for life.
next_sentence: Plain it is to us that what the world seeks through desert and wild we have within our threshold,âa stalwart laboring force, suited to the semi-tropics; if, deaf to the voice of the Zeitgeist, we refuse to use and develop these men, we risk poverty and loss.

question: Yonder in the gray past he had played with that dead boy, romping [MASK] under the solemn trees.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: John looked at it dreamily, then walked back to the house briskly, and said in a soft voice, âMammy, Iâm going awayâIâm going to be free.â  She gazed at him dimly and faltered, âNoâth, honey, is yoâ gwine Noâth agin?â  He looked out where the North Star glistened pale above the waters, and said, âYes, mammy, Iâm goingâNorth.â  Then, without another word, he went out into the narrow lane, up by the straight pines, to the same winding path, and seated himself on the great black stump, looking at the blood where the body had lain.
next_sentence: The night deepened; he thought of the boys at Johnstown.

question: In another age he might have sat among the elders of the land in purple-bordered toga; in another country mothers might have [MASK] him to the cradles.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: The more I met Alexander Crummell, the more I felt how much that world was losing which knew so little of him.
next_sentence: He did his work,âhe did it nobly and well; and yet I sorrow that here he worked alone, with so little human sympathy.

question: They were never vulgar, never [MASK], but rather rough and primitive, with an unconventionality that spent itself in loud guffaws, slaps on the back, and naps in the corner.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: They used to have a certain magnificent barbarism about them that I liked.
next_sentence: I hurried by the cottage of the misborn Neill boys.

question: And yet on two-thirds of the [MASK] there is but one crop, and that leaves the toilers in debt.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: For nine or ten months in succession the crops will come if asked: garden vegetables in April, grain in May, melons in June and July, hay in August, sweet potatoes in September, and cotton from then to Christmas.
next_sentence: Why is this?

question: Only black tenants can stand such a [MASK], and they only because they must.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: Then he went, and his neighbors too, and now only the black tenant remains; but the shadow-hand of the masterâs grand-nephew or cousin or creditor stretches out of the gray distance to collect the rack-rent remorselessly, and so the land is uncared-for and poor.
next_sentence: Ten miles we have ridden to-day and have seen no white face.

question: It is an unsatisfactory arrangement, both for hirer and hired, and is usually in vogue on poor land with hard-pressed [MASK].
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: Thus we have a laborer without capital and without wages, and an employer whose capital is largely his employeesâ wages.
next_sentence: Above the croppers come the great mass of the black population who work the land on their own responsibility, paying rent in cotton and supported by the crop-mortgage system.

question: Are not these [MASK] worth the giving?
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: Our song, our toil, our cheer, and warning have been given to this nation in blood-brotherhood.
next_sentence: Is not this work and striving?

question: They must first have the common school to teach them to read, write, and cipher; and they must have higher schools to teach teachers for the common [MASK].
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: So in the South: the mass of the freedmen at the end of the war lacked the intelligence so necessary to modern workingmen.
next_sentence: The white teachers who flocked South went to establish such a common-school system.

question: And this the [MASK] schools and the manual training and trade schools are working to accomplish.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: That one wise method of doing this lies in the closer knitting of the Negro to the great industrial possibilities of the South is a great truth.
next_sentence: But these alone are not enough.

question: For these there is one other avenue of escape toward which they have turned in increasing numbers, namely, [MASK] to town.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: Fully ninety-four per cent have struggled for land and failed, and half of them sit in hopeless serfdom.
next_sentence: A glance at the distribution of land among the black owners curiously reveals this fact.

question: Josie told me of it; she was a thin, homely girl of twenty, with a dark-brown face and thick, hard [MASK].
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: There I found at last a little school.
next_sentence: I had crossed the stream at Watertown, and rested under the great willows; then I had gone to the little cabin in the lot where Josie was resting on her way to town.

question: In yonder shadows a dark and hideously painted warrior [MASK] stealthily on, âanother and another, until three hundred had crept into the treacherous swamp.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: Men and women and children fled and fell before them as they swept into Dougherty.
next_sentence: Then the false slime closing about them called the white men from the east.

question: It was [MASK], and they were grown into fat, lazy farm-hands.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: I hurried by the cottage of the misborn Neill boys.
next_sentence: I saw the home of the Hickmans, but Albert, with his stooping shoulders, had passed from the world.

question: He felt his poverty; without a cent, without a home, without land, tools, or savings, he had entered into competition with rich, landed, skilled [MASK].
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: For the first time he sought to analyze the burden he bore upon his back, that dead-weight of social degradation partially masked behind a half-named Negro problem.
next_sentence: To be a poor man is hard, but to be a poor race in a land of dollars is the very bottom of hardships.

question: His dark-faced [MASK] sat beside him, stolid, silent.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: A young black fellow sat in it driving listlessly, his elbows on his knees.
next_sentence: âHello!â cried my driver,âhe has a most imprudent way of addressing these people, though they seem used to it,ââwhat have you got there?â  âMeat and meal,â answered the man, stopping.

question: In other [MASK] the older settlement of whites has been encircled by a broad band of blacks; in still other cases little settlements or nuclei of blacks have sprung up amid surrounding whites.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: I know some towns where a straight line drawn through the middle of the main street separates nine-tenths of the whites from nine-tenths of the blacks.
next_sentence: Usually in cities each street has its distinctive color, and only now and then do the colors meet in close proximity.

question: Next, there are the political relations, the [MASK] in social control, in group government, in laying and paying the burden of taxation.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: Secondly, and in our age chiefest, there are the economic relations,âthe methods by which individuals cooperate for earning a living, for the mutual satisfaction of wants, for the production of wealth.
next_sentence: In the fourth place there are the less tangible but highly important forms of intellectual contact and commerce, the interchange of ideas through conversation and conference, through periodicals and libraries; and, above all, the gradual formation for each community of that curious tertium quid which we call public opinion.

question: Still the price of cotton fell, and gradually the landlords deserted their plantations, and the reign of the [MASK] began.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: The legal form of service was theoretically far different; in practice, task-work or âcroppingâ was substituted for daily toil in gangs; and the slave gradually became a metayer, or tenant on shares, in name, but a laborer with indeterminate wages in fact.
next_sentence: The merchant of the Black Belt is a curious institution,âpart banker, part landlord, part banker, and part despot.

question: Ten [MASK] we have ridden to-day and have seen no white face.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: Only black tenants can stand such a system, and they only because they must.
next_sentence: A resistless feeling of depression falls slowly upon us, despite the gaudy sunshine and the green cottonfields.

question: Between them, however, and the best element of the [MASK], there is little or no intellectual commerce.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: But the increasing civilization of the Negro since then has naturally meant the development of higher classes: there are increasing numbers of ministers, teachers, physicians, merchants, mechanics, and independent farmers, who by nature and training are the aristocracy and leaders of the blacks.
next_sentence: They go to separate churches, they live in separate sections, they are strictly separated in all public gatherings, they travel separately, and they are beginning to read different papers and books.

question: All this is the [MASK] studentâs inspiration and despair.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: And of all types and kinds, what can be more instructive than the leadership of a group within a group?âthat curious double movement where real progress may be negative and actual advance be relative retrogression.
next_sentence: Now in the past the American Negro has had instructive experience in the choosing of group leaders, founding thus a peculiar dynasty which in the light of present conditions is worth while studying.

question: Beggars and [MASK] speculators rose to rule over them, and their children went astray.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: A revolution such as that of â63 is a terrible thing; they that rose rich in the morning often slept in paupersâ beds.
next_sentence: See yonder sad-colored house, with its cabins and fences and glad crops!

question: Thus, after a yearâs work, [MASK] as it was pushed, the problem looked even more difficult to grasp and solve than at the beginning.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: Making a new machine and sending out officials of duly ascertained fitness for a great work of social reform is no childâs task; but this task was even harder, for a new central organization had to be fitted on a heterogeneous and confused but already existing system of relief and control of ex-slaves; and the agents available for this work must be sought for in an army still busy with war operations,âmen in the very nature of the case ill fitted for delicate social work,âor among the questionable camp followers of an invading host.
next_sentence: Nevertheless, three things that yearâs work did, well worth the doing: it relieved a vast amount of physical suffering; it transported seven thousand fugitives from congested centres back to the farm; and, best of all, it inaugurated the crusade of the New England schoolmaâam.

question: Yet it is not [MASK] his fault.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: Here was a man paying five dollars for goods which he could have bought for three dollars cash, and raised for one dollar or one dollar and a half.
next_sentence: The Negro farmer started behind,âstarted in debt.

question: âHello! â cried my driver, âhe has a most imprudent way of addressing these people, though they seem used to it, ââwhat have you got there? â âMeat and meal, â answered the man, [MASK].
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: His dark-faced wife sat beside him, stolid, silent.
next_sentence: The meat lay uncovered in the bottom of the wagon,âa great thin side of fat pork covered with salt; the meal was in a white bushel bag.

question: Then the day ended not, and night was a dreamless terror, and joy and sleep [MASK] away.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: Tenderly then she hovered round him, till the smile fled away and Fear crouched beside the little bed.
next_sentence: I hear now that Voice at midnight calling me from dull and dreamless trance,âcrying, âThe Shadow of Death!

question: Few know of these problems, few who know notice them; and [MASK] there they are, awaiting student, artist, and seer, âa field for somebody sometime to discover.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: To-day the ferment of his striving toward self-realization is to the strife of the white world like a wheel within a wheel: beyond the Veil are smaller but like problems of ideals, of leaders and the led, of serfdom, of poverty, of order and subordination, and, through all, the Veil of Race.
next_sentence: Hither has the temptation of Hippomenes penetrated; already in this smaller world, which now indirectly and anon directly must influence the larger for good or ill, the habit is forming of interpreting the world in dollars.

question: These questions and movements are, however, overshadowed and dwarfed by the (to them) all-important question of their civil, [MASK], and economic status.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: First, we must remember that living as the blacks do in close contact with a great modern nation, and sharing, although imperfectly, the soul-life of that nation, they must necessarily be affected more or less directly by all the religious and ethical forces that are to-day moving the United States.
next_sentence: They must perpetually discuss the âNegro Problem,ââmust live, move, and have their being in it, and interpret all else in its light or darkness.

question: The function of the university is not simply to teach bread-winning, or to furnish teachers for the public schools or to be a centre of polite society; it is, above all, to be the organ of that fine adjustment between real life and the growing knowledge of life, an [MASK] which forms the secret of civilization.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: And to seek to make the blacksmith a scholar is almost as silly as the more modern scheme of making the scholar a blacksmith; almost, but not quite.
next_sentence: Such an institution the South of to-day sorely needs.

question: Of [MASK] this car is not so good as the other, but it is fairly clean and comfortable.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: Usually the races are mixed in there; but the white coach is all white.
next_sentence: The discomfort lies chiefly in the hearts of those four black men yonderâand in mine.

question: Oh, how he [MASK] him, âpitied him, âand wondered if he had the coiling twisted rope.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: With an effort he roused himself, bent forward, and looked steadily down the pathway, softly humming the âSong of the Bride,ââ  âFreudig gefÃ¼hrt, ziehet dahin.â   Amid the trees in the dim morning twilight he watched their shadows dancing and heard their horses thundering toward him, until at last they came sweeping like a storm, and he saw in front that haggard white-haired man, whose eyes flashed red with fury.
next_sentence: Then, as the storm burst round him, he rose slowly to his feet and turned his closed eyes toward the Sea.

question: And we [MASK] no word, and turned away.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: Then we two alone looked upon the child as he turned toward us with great eyes, and stretched his stringlike hands,âthe Shadow of Death!
next_sentence: He died at eventide, when the sun lay like a brooding sorrow above the western hills, veiling its face; when the winds spoke not, and the trees, the great green trees he loved, stood motionless.

question: He looked now for the first time sharply about him, and wondered he had seen so [MASK] before.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: He had left his queer thought-world and come back to a world of motion and of men.
next_sentence: He grew slowly to feel almost for the first time the Veil that lay between him and the white world; he first noticed now the oppression that had not seemed oppression before, differences that erstwhile seemed natural, restraints and slights that in his boyhood days had gone unnoticed or been greeted with a laugh.

question: An old ragged black man, honest, simple, and improvident, told us the [MASK].
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: I could imagine the place under some weird spell, and was half-minded to search out the princess.
next_sentence: The Wizard of the Northâthe Capitalistâhad rushed down in the seventies to woo this coy dark soil.

question: With all his [MASK] and lack of many elements of true manhood, he was at least open-hearted, faithful, and sincere.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: It is no idle regret with which the white South mourns the loss of the old-time Negro,âthe frank, honest, simple old servant who stood for the earlier religious age of submission and humility.
next_sentence: To-day he is gone, but who is to blame for his going?

question: The sole advantage of this small [MASK] is their freedom to choose their crops, and the increased responsibility which comes through having money transactions.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: The renters for fixed money rentals are the first of the emerging classes, and form five per cent of the families.
next_sentence: While some of the renters differ little in condition from the metayers, yet on the whole they are more intelligent and responsible persons, and are the ones who eventually become land-owners.

question: Next came the difficult question of [MASK].
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: In fifty months twenty-one million free rations were distributed at a cost of over four million dollars.
next_sentence: First, thirty thousand black men were transported from the refuges and relief stations back to the farms, back to the critical trial of a new way of working.

question: Whither [MASK] his longings and strivings, and wherefore were his heart-burnings and disappointments?
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: What seemed to him good and evil,âGod and Devil?
next_sentence: Answers to such questions can come only from a study of Negro religion as a development, through its gradual changes from the heathenism of the Gold Coast to the institutional Negro church of Chicago.

question: Thus he passed out of the preparatory school into college, and we who [MASK] him felt four more years of change, which almost transformed the tall, grave man who bowed to us commencement morning.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: And we who saw daily a new thoughtfulness growing in his eyes began to expect something of this plodding boy.
next_sentence: He had left his queer thought-world and come back to a world of motion and of men.

question: The silently growing assumption of this age is that the probation of [MASK] is past, and that the backward races of to-day are of proven inefficiency and not worth the saving.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: Do the Sorrow Songs sing true?
next_sentence: Such an assumption is the arrogance of peoples irreverent toward Time and ignorant of the deeds of men.

question: Men call the shadow prejudice, and learnedly explain it as the natural defence of [MASK] against barbarism, learning against ignorance, purity against crime, the âhigherâ against the âlowerâ races.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: while sociologists gleefully count his bastards and his prostitutes, the very soul of the toiling, sweating black man is darkened by the shadow of a vast despair.
next_sentence: To which the Negro cries Amen!

question: And this latter [MASK] can be settled in but one way, âby a first-hand study of the facts.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: But all this can be said of higher education throughout the land; it is the almost inevitable incident of educational growth, and leaves the deeper question of the legitimate demand for the higher training of Negroes untouched.
next_sentence: If we leave out of view all institutions which have not actually graduated students from a course higher than that of a New England high school, even though they be called colleges; if then we take the thirty-four remaining institutions, we may clear up many misapprehensions by asking searchingly, What kind of institutions are they?

question: Freedom, too, the long-sought, we still seek, âthe freedom of [MASK] and limb, the freedom to work and think, the freedom to love and aspire.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: The power of the ballot we need in sheer self-defence,âelse what shall save us from a second slavery?
next_sentence: Work, culture, liberty,âall these we need, not singly but together, not successively but together, each growing and aiding each, and all striving toward that vaster ideal that swims before the Negro people, the ideal of human brotherhood, gained through the unifying ideal of Race; the ideal of fostering and developing the traits and talents of the Negro, not in opposition to or contempt for other races, but rather in large conformity to the greater ideals of the American Republic, in order that some day on American soil two world-races may give each to each those characteristics both so sadly lack.

question: Such class lines are by no means [MASK]; they vary, one might almost say, with the price of cotton.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: The rest, over eighty per cent, are poor and ignorant, fairly honest and well meaning, plodding, and to a degree shiftless, with some but not great sexual looseness.
next_sentence: The degree of ignorance cannot easily be expressed.

question: He worked and toiled, week by week, day by day, [MASK] by month.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: The days sped by, and the dark young clergyman labored; he wrote his sermons carefully; he intoned his prayers with a soft, earnest voice; he haunted the streets and accosted the wayfarers; he visited the sick, and knelt beside the dying.
next_sentence: And yet month by month the congregation dwindled, week by week the hollow walls echoed more sharply, day by day the calls came fewer and fewer, and day by day the third temptation sat clearer and still more clearly within the Veil; a temptation, as it were, bland and smiling, with just a shade of mockery in its smooth tones.

question: The educational system striving to complete itself saw new obstacles and a field of work ever [MASK] and deeper.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: The land saw glimpses of a new destiny and the stirring of new ideals.
next_sentence: The Negro colleges, hurriedly founded, were inadequately equipped, illogically distributed, and of varying efficiency and grade; the normal and high schools were doing little more than common-school work, and the common schools were training but a third of the children who ought to be in them, and training these too often poorly.

question: With this [MASK] there is an economic opening, and perhaps peace and some prosperity.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: Patience, humility, and adroitness must, in these growing black youth, replace impulse, manliness, and courage.
next_sentence: Without this there is riot, migration, or crime.

question: Well sped, my boy, before the world had dubbed your ambition insolence, had held your ideals [MASK], and taught you to cringe and bow.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: For what, forsooth, shall a Negro want with pride amid the studied humiliations of fifty million fellows?
next_sentence: Better far this nameless void that stops my life than a sea of sorrow for you.

question: By taking away their best equipped teachers and leaders, by [MASK] the door of opportunity in the faces of their bolder and brighter minds, will you make them satisfied with their lot?
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: Suppose we seek to remedy this by making them laborers and nothing more: they are not fools, they have tasted of the Tree of Life, and they will not cease to think, will not cease attempting to read the riddle of the world.
next_sentence: or will you not rather transfer their leading from the hands of men taught to think to the hands of untrained demagogues?

question: It would certainly be soothing if one could readily believe all this; and yet there are too many ugly facts for [MASK] to be thus easily explained away.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: Nor does it altogether satisfy the conscience of the modern world to be told complacently that all this has been right and proper, the fated triumph of strength over weakness, of righteousness over evil, of superiors over inferiors.
next_sentence: We feel and know that there are many delicate differences in race psychology, numberless changes that our crude social measurements are not yet able to follow minutely, which explain much of history and social development.

question: One can easily see how a person who saw slavery thus from his fatherâs parlors, and sees freedom on the streets of a great city, fails to grasp or comprehend the whole of the [MASK] picture.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: This is a vast change from the situation in the past, when, through the close contact of master and house-servant in the patriarchal big house, one found the best of both races in close contact and sympathy, while at the same time the squalor and dull round of toil among the field-hands was removed from the sight and hearing of the family.
next_sentence: On the other hand, the settled belief of the mass of the Negroes that the Southern white people do not have the black manâs best interests at heart has been intensified in later years by this continual daily contact of the better class of blacks with the worst representatives of the white race.

question: It is wrong to encourage a man or a people in evil-doing; it is wrong to aid and abet a [MASK] crime simply because it is unpopular not to do so.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: In failing thus to state plainly and unequivocally the legitimate demands of their people, even at the cost of opposing an honored leader, the thinking classes of American Negroes would shirk a heavy responsibility,âa responsibility to themselves, a responsibility to the struggling masses, a responsibility to the darker races of men whose future depends so largely on this American experiment, but especially a responsibility to this nation,âthis common Fatherland.
next_sentence: The growing spirit of kindliness and reconciliation between the North and South after the frightful difference of a generation ago ought to be a source of deep congratulation to all, and especially to those whose mistreatment caused the war; but if that reconciliation is to be marked by the industrial slavery and civic death of those same black men, with permanent legislation into a position of inferiority, then those black men, if they are really men, are called upon by every consideration of patriotism and loyalty to oppose such a course by all civilized methods, even though such opposition involves disagreement with Mr. Booker T. Washington.

question: And their weak wings beat against their barriers, âbarriers of caste, of youth, of life; at last, in dangerous moments, against everything that opposed even a [MASK].
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: Ill could they be content, born without and beyond the World.
next_sentence: The ten years that follow youth, the years when first the realization comes that life is leading somewhere,âthese were the years that passed after I left my little school.

question: She had [MASK] a man and a farm twenty miles away.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: He showed me where Simon Thompson had bought a bit of ground and a home; but his daughter Lana, a plump, brown, slow girl, was not there.
next_sentence: We wound on down the stream till we came to a gate that I did not recognize, but the boy insisted that it was âUncle Birdâs.â The farm was fat with the growing crop.

question: He had [MASK] so childish a thing.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: Hate?
next_sentence: Despair?

question: All this we can only learn by [MASK] contact with the masses, and not by wholesale arguments covering millions separate in time and space, and differing widely in training and culture.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: And yet how little we really know of these millions,âof their daily lives and longings, of their homely joys and sorrows, of their real shortcomings and the meaning of their crimes!
next_sentence: To-day, then, my reader, let us turn our faces to the Black Belt of Georgia and seek simply to know the condition of the black farm-laborers of one county there.

question: Such an institution, from its wide powers, great responsibilities, large control of moneys, and [MASK] conspicuous position, was naturally open to repeated and bitter attack.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: Its failures were the result of bad local agents, the inherent difficulties of the work, and national neglect.
next_sentence: It sustained a searching Congressional investigation at the instance of Fernando Wood in 1870.

question: Fully ninety-four per cent have [MASK] for land and failed, and half of them sit in hopeless serfdom.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: Out of the hard economic conditions of this portion of the Black Belt, only six per cent of the population have succeeded in emerging into peasant proprietorship; and these are not all firmly fixed, but grow and shrink in number with the wavering of the cotton-market.
next_sentence: For these there is one other avenue of escape toward which they have turned in increasing numbers, namely, migration to town.

question: Even the booby [MASK] in reading showed a little comforting progress.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: The attendance was larger and the children were a shade cleaner this week.
next_sentence: So John settled himself with renewed patience this afternoon.

question: It is so much easier to assume that we [MASK] it all.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: We seldom study the condition of the Negro to-day honestly and carefully.
next_sentence: Or perhaps, having already reached conclusions in our own minds, we are loth to have them disturbed by facts.

question: Their better character and greater shrewdness enable them to gain, perhaps to demand, better terms in rents; rented farms, varying from forty to a hundred [MASK], bear an average rental of about fifty-four dollars a year.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: While some of the renters differ little in condition from the metayers, yet on the whole they are more intelligent and responsible persons, and are the ones who eventually become land-owners.
next_sentence: The men who conduct such farms do not long remain renters; either they sink to metayers, or with a successful series of harvests rise to be land-owners.

question: In the history of nearly all other races and peoples the doctrine preached at such crises has been that manly self-respect is worth more than lands and houses, and that a people who voluntarily [MASK] such respect, or cease striving for it, are not worth civilizing.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: In other periods of intensified prejudice all the Negroâs tendency to self-assertion has been called forth; at this period a policy of submission is advocated.
next_sentence: In answer to this, it has been claimed that the Negro can survive only through submission.

question: If the tenant worked hard and raised a large crop, his rent was raised the next year; if that year the [MASK] failed, his corn was confiscated and his mule sold for debt.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: If cotton rose in price, the rent rose even higher; if cotton fell, the rent remained or followed reluctantly.
next_sentence: There were, of course, exceptions to this,âcases of personal kindness and forbearance; but in the vast majority of cases the rule was to extract the uttermost farthing from the mass of the black farm laborers.

question: On we wind, through sand and pines and glimpses of [MASK] plantations, till there creeps into sight a cluster of buildings, âwood and brick, mills and houses, and scattered cabins.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: It will only increase their rent.
next_sentence: It seemed quite a village.

question: The renters for fixed money rentals are the [MASK] of the emerging classes, and form five per cent of the families.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: They are usually young unmarried persons, some being women; and when they marry they sink to the class of metayers, or, more seldom, become renters.
next_sentence: The sole advantage of this small class is their freedom to choose their crops, and the increased responsibility which comes through having money transactions.

question: So he moved here, where the rent is higher, the land [MASK], and the owner inflexible; he rents a forty-dollar mule for twenty dollars a year.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: Until last year he had good luck renting; then cotton fell, and the sheriff seized and sold all he had.
next_sentence: Poor lad!âa slave at twenty-two.

question: Daily he found himself shrinking from the choked and [MASK] life of his native town.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: A tinge of sarcasm crept into his speech, and a vague bitterness into his life; and he sat long hours wondering and planning a way around these crooked things.
next_sentence: And yet he always planned to go back to Altamaha,âalways planned to work there.

question: Even the kind hands that [MASK] themselves toward him from out the depths of that dull morning seemed but parts of the purple shadows.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: And then from that Vision Splendid all the glory faded slowly away, and left an earth gray and stern rolling on beneath a dark despair.
next_sentence: He saw them coldly, and asked, âWhy should I strive by special grace when the way of the world is closed to me?â All gently yet, the hands urged him on,âthe hands of young John Jay, that daring fatherâs daring son; the hands of the good folk of Boston, that free city.

question: [MASK] became to him a real thing and not a dream.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: The free Negro leader early arose and his chief characteristic was intense earnestness and deep feeling on the slavery question.
next_sentence: His religion became darker and more intense, and into his ethics crept a note of revenge, into his songs a day of reckoning close at hand.

question: This, then, is the end of his striving: to be a co-worker in the kingdom of culture, to escape both death and isolation, to husband and [MASK] his best powers and his latent genius.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: He simply wishes to make it possible for a man to be both a Negro and an American, without being cursed and spit upon by his fellows, without having the doors of Opportunity closed roughly in his face.
next_sentence: These powers of body and mind have in the past been strangely wasted, dispersed, or forgotten.

question: But full half the black [MASK] followed him proudly to the station, and carried his queer little trunk and many bundles.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: âItâll spoil him,âruin him,â they said; and they talked as though they knew.
next_sentence: And there they shook and shook hands, and the girls kissed him shyly and the boys clapped him on the back.

question: Opposite the door is a [MASK] home-made desk.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: It is a tiny plank-house, perhaps ten by twenty, and has within a double row of rough unplaned benches, resting mostly on legs, sometimes on boxes.
next_sentence: In one corner are the ruins of a stove, and in the other a dim blackboard.

question: The guiding of [MASK] and the deft coordination of deed is at once the path of honor and humanity.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: To stimulate wildly weak and untrained minds is to play with mighty fires; to flout their striving idly is to welcome a harvest of brutish crime and shameless lethargy in our very laps.
next_sentence: And so, in this great question of reconciling three vast and partially contradictory streams of thought, the one panacea of Education leaps to the lips of all:âsuch human training as will best use the labor of all men without enslaving or brutalizing; such training as will give us poise to encourage the prejudices that bulwark society, and to stamp out those that in sheer barbarity deafen us to the wail of prisoned souls within the Veil, and the mounting fury of shackled men.

question: Yes, seven; but they hadnât been to school this year, âcouldnât afford books and [MASK], and couldnât spare their work.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: Children?
next_sentence: There go part of them to the fields now,âthree big boys astride mules, and a strapping girl with bare brown legs.

question: He is smooth-faced and brown, and is fencing up his [MASK].
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: Two childrenâa boy and a girlâare hoeing sturdily in the fields on the farm where Corliss works.
next_sentence: He used to run a successful cotton-gin, but the Cotton Seed Oil Trust has forced the price of ginning so low that he says it hardly pays him.

question: Thirteen hundred human beings here obeyed the call of one, âwere his in [MASK], and largely in soul.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: Away down the Baysan road, where the broad flat fields are flanked by great oak forests, is a plantation; many thousands of acres it used to run, here and there, and beyond the great wood.
next_sentence: One of them lives there yet,âa short, stocky man, his dull-brown face seamed and drawn, and his tightly curled hair gray-white.

question: He [MASK] back and smiled toward the sea, whence rose the strange melody, away from the dark shadows where lay the noise of horses galloping, galloping on.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: Clear and high the faint sweet melody rose and fluttered like a living thing, so that the very earth trembled as with the tramp of horses and murmur of angry men.
next_sentence: With an effort he roused himself, bent forward, and looked steadily down the pathway, softly humming the âSong of the Bride,ââ  âFreudig gefÃ¼hrt, ziehet dahin.â   Amid the trees in the dim morning twilight he watched their shadows dancing and heard their horses thundering toward him, until at last they came sweeping like a storm, and he saw in front that haggard white-haired man, whose eyes flashed red with fury.

question: Tall and black, they move slowly by, and seem in the sinister [MASK] to flit before the city like dim warning ghosts.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: When at evening the winds come swelling from the east, and the great pall of the cityâs smoke hangs wearily above the valley, then the red west glows like a dreamland down Carlisle Street, and, at the tolling of the supper-bell, throws the passing forms of students in dark silhouette against the sky.
next_sentence: Perhaps they are; for this is Wells Institute, and these black students have few dealings with the white city below.

question: All they furnish is their labor; the land-owner furnishes land, stock, tools, seed, and house; and at the end of the year the laborer gets from a [MASK] to a half of the crop.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: The croppers are entirely without capital, even in the limited sense of food or money to keep them from seed-time to harvest.
next_sentence: Out of his share, however, comes pay and interest for food and clothing advanced him during the year.

question: The beauty of the group lies in its simple unity: âa broad [MASK] of green rising from the red street and mingled roses and peaches; north and south, two plain and stately halls; and in the midst, half hidden in ivy, a larger building, boldly graceful, sparingly decorated, and with one low spire.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: On one, toward the west, the setting sun throws three buildings in bold relief against the sky.
next_sentence: It is a restful group, âone never looks for more; it is all here, all intelligible.

question: The young men [MASK] between the ages of twenty-five and thirty-five; the young women between twenty and thirty.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: Today, however, very few of the boys and less than a fifth of the Negro girls under twenty are married.
next_sentence: Such postponement is due to the difficulty of earning sufficient to rear and support a family; and it undoubtedly leads, in the country districts, to sexual immorality.

question: And to themselves in these the days that try their souls, the chance to soar in the dim blue air above the smoke is to their finer spirits boon and guerdon for what they [MASK] on earth by being black.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: Herein the longing of black men must have respect: the rich and bitter depth of their experience, the unknown treasures of their inner life, the strange rendings of nature they have seen, may give the world new points of view and make their loving, living, and doing precious to all human hearts.
next_sentence: I sit with Shakespeare and he winces not.

question: They can be met in but one way, âby the breadth and [MASK] of human reason, by catholicity of taste and culture.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: They must be recognized as facts, but unpleasant facts; things that stand in the way of civilization and religion and common decency.
next_sentence: And so, too, the native ambition and aspiration of men, even though they be black, backward, and ungraceful, must not lightly be dealt with.

question: It is full easy now to see that the man who lost home, fortune, and family at a stroke, and saw his [MASK] ruled by âmules and niggers, â was really benefited by the passing of slavery.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: It is all well enough for us of another generation to wax wise with advice to those who bore the burden in the heat of the day.
next_sentence: It is not difficult now to say to the young freedman, cheated and cuffed about who has seen his fatherâs head beaten to a jelly and his own mother namelessly assaulted, that the meek shall inherit the earth.

question: The [MASK] was larger and the children were a shade cleaner this week.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: Nevertheless, he struggled hopefully on, and seemed to see at last some glimmering of dawn.
next_sentence: Even the booby class in reading showed a little comforting progress.

question: Now and then one may find such a cabin kept scrupulously neat, with merry steaming fireplaces and hospitable [MASK]; but the majority are dirty and dilapidated, smelling of eating and sleeping, poorly ventilated, and anything but homes.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: A bed or two, a table, a wooden chest, and a few chairs compose the furniture; while a stray show-bill or a newspaper makes up the decorations for the walls.
next_sentence: Above all, the cabins are crowded.

question: He sought to teach them at the church, and had outraged their deepest [MASK].
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: He had come to save his people, and before he left the depot he had hurt them.
next_sentence: He had schooled himself to be respectful to the Judge, and then blundered into his front door.

question: Forty-five years he had labored on this farm, beginning with nothing, and still having [MASK].
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: I remember one big red-eyed black whom we met by the roadside.
next_sentence: To be sure, he had given four children a common-school training, and perhaps if the new fence-law had not allowed unfenced crops in West Dougherty he might have raised a little stock and kept ahead.

question: Of nearly all the songs, however, the music is [MASK] sorrowful.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: Purely secular songs are few in number, partly because many of them were turned into hymns by a change of words, partly because the frolics were seldom heard by the stranger, and the music less often caught.
next_sentence: The ten master songs I have mentioned tell in word and music of trouble and exile, of strife and hiding; they grope toward some unseen power and sigh for rest in the End.

question: He [MASK] his arms and hurried wildly up the path.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: I cannot live here longer.â And then the fierce, buried anger surged up into his throat.
next_sentence: The great brown sea lay silent.

question: They are not happy, these black [MASK] whom we meet throughout this region.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: It is a depressing place,âbare, unshaded, with no charm of past association, only a memory of forced human toil,ânow, then, and before the war.
next_sentence: There is little of the joyous abandon and playfulness which we are wont to associate with the plantation Negro.

question: Their cabins [MASK] better than most, and the farm, with machinery and fertilizers, is much more business-like than any in the county, although the manager drives hard bargains in wages.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: He owns almost a Rhode Island county, with thousands of acres and hundreds of black laborers.
next_sentence: When now we turn and look five miles above, there on the edge of town are five houses of prostitutes,âtwo of blacks and three of whites; and in one of the houses of the whites a worthless black boy was harbored too openly two years ago; so he was hanged for rape.

question: Idle words; he might have borne his burden more bravely than we, âaye, and found it [MASK] too, some day; for surely, surely this is not the end.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: Better far this nameless void that stops my life than a sea of sorrow for you.
next_sentence: Surely there shall yet dawn some mighty morning to lift the Veil and set the prisoned free.

question: Considerable sums of money are collected and expended here, employment is found for the [MASK], strangers are introduced, news is disseminated and charity distributed.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: Entertainments, suppers, and lectures are held beside the five or six regular weekly religious services.
next_sentence: At the same time this social, intellectual, and economic centre is a religious centre of great power.

question: Then the national election took place; and the administration, with a vote of renewed confidence from the country, addressed itself to the [MASK] more seriously.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: The debates wandered over the whole policy of the administration and the general question of slavery, without touching very closely the specific merits of the measure in hand.
next_sentence: A conference between the two branches of Congress agreed upon a carefully drawn measure which contained the chief provisions of Sumnerâs bill, but made the proposed organization a department independent of both the War and the Treasury officials.

question: Usually in cities each street has its distinctive color, and only now and then do the colors [MASK] in close proximity.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: In other towns the older settlement of whites has been encircled by a broad band of blacks; in still other cases little settlements or nuclei of blacks have sprung up amid surrounding whites.
next_sentence: Even in the country something of this segregation is manifest in the smaller areas, and of course in the larger phenomena of the Black Belt.

question: One was [MASK], listlessly bent forward, his elbows on his knees, âa happy-go-lucky, careless picture of irresponsibility.
source_info: The Souls of Black Folk by Bois, W. E. Burghardt Du
title: The Souls of Black Folk
prev_sentence: A couple of young black fellows passed us in a muleteam, with several bushels of loose corn in the ear.
next_sentence: The other was fast asleep in the bottom of the wagon.
